artist: Artist: Utagawa Hiroshige; Publisher: Nishimuraya Yohachi
catalogue_raissonne: Ukiyo-e shūka 14 (1981), Hiroshige list, p. 243, horizontal ōban #091.06
creditline: Gift of Louis W. Hill, Jr.
inscription:
Ciisa ki wo/ saimaki to iu/ kurumaebi/ Shibaura ni koso/ tsumite okuran

(When they are smaller/ prawns have a pattern on their shells/ that looks like the bands on a sheath./ It helped the fisherman of Shinaura beach/ band them together and catch then en masse.)

by Toshiyado no Tomiharu
medium: Woodblock print (nishiki-e); ink and color on paper
portfolio: From Untitled series of fish known as Large Fish
signed: Ichiryūsai Hiroshige ga 一立斎広重画
text:
Prawns and mackerel, harvested by the Japanese in late summer and early autumn, are typically garnished with sprigs of smartweed, a summer herb. A kyōka poem by Toshinoya no Tomiharu is inscribed at the upper right.

When they are smaller
prawns have a pattern on their shells that looks like the bands on a sheath.
It helped the fishermen of Shibaura Beach
band them together and catch them en masse.
title: Horse Mackerel, Freshwater Prawns, and Seaweed
